title: Luke Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Luke chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Luke Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Luke Chapter 6.

questions.question: What did Jesus' disciples do in the corn fields on the sabbath according to Luke 6:1?
options: Plucked ears of corn and rubbed them in their hands
questions.correctAnswer: Plucked ears of corn and rubbed them in their hands
questions.explanation: Luke 6:1 describes how Jesus' disciples plucked ears of corn and rubbed them in their hands to eat on the sabbath.

questions.question: Who questioned Jesus' disciples about what they were doing on the sabbath in Luke 6:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The Pharisees
questions.explanation: Luke 6:2 states that certain of the Pharisees asked why the disciples did what was not lawful on the sabbath.

questions.question: What example did Jesus give to defend his disciples eating on the sabbath in Luke 6:3-4?
options: What David did when he ate the shewbread
The manna given to the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: What David did when he ate the shewbread
questions.explanation: Jesus referred to David eating the shewbread, which was lawful only for priests, to illustrate lawful exceptions on the sabbath (Luke 6:3-4).

questions.question: According to Luke 6:5, who is Lord of the sabbath?
questions.correctAnswer: The Son of man
questions.explanation: Jesus declared in Luke 6:5 that the Son of man is Lord also of the sabbath.

questions.question: What physical ailment did the man have in the synagogue that Jesus healed on the sabbath according to Luke 6:6-7?
questions.correctAnswer: A withered right hand
questions.explanation: Luke 6:6-7 describes a man whose right hand was withered whom Jesus healed in the synagogue on the sabbath.

questions.question: What question did Jesus ask regarding doing good or evil on the sabbath in Luke 6:9?
options: Is it lawful on the sabbath days to do good or to do evil?
Should we rest on the sabbath or work?
Is the sabbath more important than the temple?
Can the sabbath laws be changed?
questions.correctAnswer: Is it lawful on the sabbath days to do good or to do evil?
questions.explanation: In Luke 6:9, Jesus asks if it is lawful to do good or evil on the sabbath, emphasizing doing good.

questions.question: How did Jesus heal the man with the withered hand according to Luke 6:10?
options: He told him to stretch forth his hand, which was then restored
He laid hands on him and prayed
He spoke a word and the hand was healed
He anointed the hand with oil
questions.correctAnswer: He told him to stretch forth his hand, which was then restored
questions.explanation: Luke 6:10 explains that Jesus told the man to stretch forth his hand, and it was restored whole.

questions.question: What did Jesus do on the mountain before choosing the twelve apostles in Luke 6:12-13?
questions.correctAnswer: Prayed all night to God
questions.explanation: According to Luke 6:12, Jesus went out into a mountain and prayed all night before choosing the twelve apostles.

questions.question: Which of these was NOT named among the twelve apostles in Luke 6:14-16?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: Paul is not listed among the twelve apostles in Luke 6:14-16; the others are named there.

questions.question: From where did the great multitude come to hear Jesus and be healed according to Luke 6:17-18?
options: All Judaea, Jerusalem, and the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon
questions.correctAnswer: All Judaea, Jerusalem, and the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon
questions.explanation: Luke 6:17-18 states the multitude came from Judaea, Jerusalem, and the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon.

questions.question: According to Luke 6:20, who did Jesus say are blessed?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor
questions.explanation: Luke 6:20 records Jesus saying, 'Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.'

questions.question: True or False: Luke 6:27 teaches to love your enemies and do good to those who hate you.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 6:27 explicitly instructs to love your enemies and do good to those who hate you.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 6:31 says to do to others as you would have them do to you.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 6:31 teaches the Golden Rule: do to others as you would have them do to you.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 6:37 says to judge others so that you will not be judged.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 6:37 says 'Judge not, and ye shall not be judged,' so the statement is false.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Luke 6:39: 'Can the blind lead the _____? shall they not both fall into the ditch?'
questions.correctAnswer: blind
questions.explanation: Luke 6:39 uses the phrase 'Can the blind lead the blind? shall they not both fall into the ditch?'

medium.title: Luke Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Luke Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Luke 6 teach us about prioritizing mercy and compassion over strict legalism?
options: Doing good and saving life is lawful on the Sabbath
Strictly avoiding work on the Sabbath at all costs
Only priests may perform acts on the Sabbath
Avoiding healing on the Sabbath to prevent accusations
questions.correctAnswer: Doing good and saving life is lawful on the Sabbath
questions.explanation: Luke 6:9 shows Jesus teaching that it is lawful to do good and save life on the Sabbath, emphasizing mercy over rigid legalism. This is supported by verses 6-10 where Jesus heals a man on the Sabbath, illustrating compassion.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feeling rejected for their faith. Based on Luke 6, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and reward?
options: They will be rewarded greatly in heaven for enduring hatred
They should avoid people who hate them
They will have no reward if they suffer
Rejection means God has abandoned them
questions.correctAnswer: They will be rewarded greatly in heaven for enduring hatred
questions.explanation: Luke 6:22-23 encourages believers that when they face hatred and rejection for the Son of man's sake, they should rejoice because their reward is great in heaven. This teaches perseverance and hope.

questions.question: How does Luke 6 instruct believers to respond to enemies and those who mistreat them?
options: Love your enemies, bless those who curse you, and pray for those who mistreat you
questions.correctAnswer: Love your enemies, bless those who curse you, and pray for those who mistreat you
questions.explanation: Luke 6:27-28 teaches love, blessing, and prayer for enemies and those who mistreat believers, highlighting radical love and forgiveness as Christ's standard.

questions.question: According to Luke 6, what attitude should believers have regarding judging others?
options: Do not judge or condemn, but forgive to be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: Do not judge or condemn, but forgive to be forgiven
questions.explanation: Luke 6:37 instructs believers not to judge or condemn others but to forgive, promising that they will be forgiven themselves. This encourages humility and mercy in interpersonal relationships.

questions.question: What practical teaching about generosity is found in Luke 6?
options: Give to everyone who asks without expecting anything back
Give only to those who can return the favor
Give only in public to be praised
questions.correctAnswer: Give to everyone who asks without expecting anything back
questions.explanation: Luke 6:30-35 teaches believers to give generously to all who ask, without expecting repayment, and to love even those who are ungrateful, reflecting God's kindness and generosity.

questions.question: What does Luke 6 teach about humility and self-examination before helping others?
options: Remove the beam from your own eye before helping your brother with his mote
Ignore your own faults when correcting others
Judge others harshly to keep them accountable
questions.correctAnswer: Remove the beam from your own eye before helping your brother with his mote
questions.explanation: Luke 6:41-42 teaches that one must address their own significant faults before correcting others' minor faults, promoting humility and self-awareness.

questions.question: How does Luke 6 describe the importance of hearing and obeying Jesus' teachings for a believer's stability in life?
options: Like a man who builds his house on a rock and withstands floods
Like a man who builds a house without a foundation and it falls
Like a man who ignores building a house
Like a man who builds a house on sand and it lasts forever
questions.correctAnswer: Like a man who builds his house on a rock and withstands floods
questions.explanation: Luke 6:47-48 explains that those who hear and obey Jesus are like someone who builds on a rock foundation, able to withstand life's trials and storms, symbolizing spiritual stability.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 6, it is acceptable to build your life without obedience to Jesus and still expect to withstand life's challenges.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 6:49 states that those who hear but do not obey Jesus are like a man who builds a house without a foundation, which falls immediately when faced with storms, emphasizing the necessity of obedience.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 6 teaches that loving only those who love you is sufficient for Christian living.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 6:32-35 teaches that loving only those who love you is what sinners do; instead, believers are called to love their enemies and do good without expecting anything in return, reflecting God's love.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Luke 6 says, 'Give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, pressed down, and shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: bosom
questions.explanation: Luke 6:38 teaches that generous giving will be returned abundantly, using the imagery of a 'bosom' where blessings overflow, encouraging generous stewardship.

questions.question: How should a believer respond when falsely praised by others, according to Luke 6?
options: Be cautious, as this is how false prophets were treated
Accept it as proof of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Be cautious, as this is how false prophets were treated
questions.explanation: Luke 6:26 warns that when all men speak well of you, it is a sign similar to how false prophets were treated, urging believers to remain humble and discerning.

questions.question: What does Luke 6 say about the source and result of a person's words and actions?
options: A good man brings forth good from the good treasure of his heart, and an evil man brings forth evil
Words and actions are unrelated to the heart
Only actions matter, not the heart
Good words can come from an evil heart
questions.correctAnswer: A good man brings forth good from the good treasure of his heart, and an evil man brings forth evil
questions.explanation: Luke 6:45 teaches that the abundance of the heart determines what a person speaks and does, emphasizing the importance of inner transformation.

questions.question: According to Luke 6, how should believers treat those who take their possessions?
options: Do not stop them and even give more if asked
questions.correctAnswer: Do not stop them and even give more if asked
questions.explanation: Luke 6:29-30 instructs believers to offer the other cheek and not forbid someone from taking more, teaching radical generosity and non-retaliation.

questions.question: How does Luke 6 encourage believers to approach prayer and personal devotion?
options: Spend time in solitary, all-night prayer for guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Spend time in solitary, all-night prayer for guidance
questions.explanation: Luke 6:12 shows Jesus going out to a mountain and praying all night before choosing the twelve apostles, underscoring the importance of devoted, solitary prayer for important decisions.

questions.question: What does Luke 6 say about the character of a disciple in relation to their master?
options: A disciple is not above his master, but everyone perfected will be like the master
A disciple is always superior to the master
A disciple does not need to follow the master
A disciple should only imitate some of the master's actions
questions.correctAnswer: A disciple is not above his master, but everyone perfected will be like the master
questions.explanation: Luke 6:40 teaches that discipleship involves humility and growth toward becoming like the master, emphasizing obedience and spiritual maturity.

hard.title: Luke Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Luke Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Luke 6:4, Jesus refers to David eating the shewbread, which was lawful only for whom to eat?
questions.correctAnswer: The priests alone
questions.explanation: Luke 6:4 states that the shewbread was not lawful to be eaten except by the priests, highlighting a cultural and religious context of priestly exclusivity in temple practices.

questions.question: What title does Jesus claim for Himself in relation to the Sabbath in Luke 6:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Lord of the Sabbath
questions.explanation: In Luke 6:5, Jesus declares Himself 'Lord also of the sabbath,' asserting His authority over Sabbath observance and foreshadowing His role in redefining Mosaic law.

questions.question: According to Luke 6:9, what question does Jesus pose about the lawfulness of actions on the Sabbath?
options: Is it lawful to do good or to do evil, to save life or to destroy it?
Is it lawful to rest or to work?
Is it lawful to pray or to speak?
Is it lawful to fast or to feast?
questions.correctAnswer: Is it lawful to do good or to do evil, to save life or to destroy it?
questions.explanation: Jesus challenges the Pharisees' strict interpretation of Sabbath law by emphasizing the higher moral principle of doing good and saving life (Luke 6:9).

questions.question: Who was chosen and named as apostles by Jesus in Luke 6:13-16?
options: Simon Peter, Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Simon called Zelotes, Judas brother of James, Judas Iscariot
Peter, John, Paul, James, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, Simon, Judas, Barnabas, Timothy
Andrew, Peter, John, Thomas, Matthew, Judas, Bartholomew, James, Paul, Simon Zelotes, Barnabas, Silas
Peter, Andrew, James, John, Thomas, Paul, Barnabas, Judas, Matthias, Philip, Bartholomew, John Mark
questions.correctAnswer: Simon Peter, Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Simon called Zelotes, Judas brother of James, Judas Iscariot
questions.explanation: Luke 6:14-16 provides the specific list of the twelve apostles chosen by Jesus, reflecting the foundational leadership of the early church.

questions.question: The crowds that gathered to hear Jesus and be healed in Luke 6:17-19 came from which regions?
questions.correctAnswer: Judaea, Jerusalem, Tyre, and Sidon
questions.explanation: Luke 6:17 mentions the geographic diversity of the crowd, indicating both Jewish and Gentile regions, which underscores Jesus' expanding ministry beyond Israel.

questions.question: In the Beatitudes of Luke 6:20-23, who does Jesus say are 'blessed' and why?
options: The poor, the hungry, the weeping, and those hated for the Son of man's sake, because theirs is the kingdom of God and great reward in heaven
The rich and powerful, because they have earthly dominion
The scribes and Pharisees, because they uphold the law
The rulers and kings, because they govern justly
questions.correctAnswer: The poor, the hungry, the weeping, and those hated for the Son of man's sake, because theirs is the kingdom of God and great reward in heaven
questions.explanation: Luke 6:20-23 contrasts earthly status with divine blessing, emphasizing reversal of fortunes and God's care for the marginalized.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Luke 6:24-26 where Jesus pronounces woes against certain groups?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, contrasting blessings and woes
questions.explanation: The structure of blessings followed by woes in Luke 6:20-26 is an example of chiasm, highlighting thematic reversals and moral contrasts.

questions.question: According to Luke 6:27-36, which of the following best summarizes Jesus' teaching about love and mercy?
options: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, and be merciful as your Father is merciful
Love only those who love you and repay good for good
Avoid enemies and seek revenge when wronged
Keep strict justice and judge others harshly
questions.correctAnswer: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, and be merciful as your Father is merciful
questions.explanation: This passage (Luke 6:27-36) emphasizes radical love and mercy that transcends natural human inclinations, reflecting God's character.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Greek term translated as 'virtue' in Luke 6:19, referring to the power that went out from Jesus?
options: Dunamis - signifying miraculous power or strength
questions.correctAnswer: Dunamis - signifying miraculous power or strength
questions.explanation: The term 'virtue' in Luke 6:19 comes from the Greek 'dunamis,' indicating the miraculous power flowing from Jesus to heal and restore, highlighting His divine authority.

questions.question: In Luke 6:39-40, Jesus uses the metaphor of the blind leading the blind. What is the main lesson conveyed by this metaphor?
options: A disciple must not be above his master and should learn properly to avoid failure
Blind people can lead others safely if they try hard
Leaders should be chosen regardless of their knowledge
Blindness is a physical condition unrelated to teaching
questions.correctAnswer: A disciple must not be above his master and should learn properly to avoid failure
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Luke 6:39-40 warns about faulty guidance and stresses the importance of discipleship and proper learning under a competent master.

questions.question: Which theme in Luke 6:41-42 is illustrated by the metaphor of the 'mote' and the 'beam' in the eye?
options: Hypocrisy and self-examination before judging others
questions.correctAnswer: Hypocrisy and self-examination before judging others
questions.explanation: Jesus uses this vivid metaphor in Luke 6:41-42 to expose hypocrisy, teaching that one must address their own flaws before correcting others.

questions.question: What does Luke 6:43-45 teach about the relationship between a person's heart and their actions or words?
options: A good man brings forth good from the good treasure of his heart, and an evil man brings forth evil from the evil treasure
Actions are unrelated to a person's heart
Only words reflect the heart, not actions
Good deeds can come from an evil heart
questions.correctAnswer: A good man brings forth good from the good treasure of his heart, and an evil man brings forth evil from the evil treasure
questions.explanation: This passage (Luke 6:43-45) uses the analogy of trees and their fruit to illustrate that inner character determines outward behavior and speech.

questions.question: In Luke 6:46-49, Jesus compares those who hear and do His sayings to a man who built a house on what kind of foundation?
questions.correctAnswer: A rock foundation
questions.explanation: Jesus uses the imagery of a house built on rock to symbolize stability and resilience for those who obey His teachings (Luke 6:48).

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 6:37, Jesus teaches that judging others will result in being judged oneself.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 6:37 clearly states 'Judge not, and ye shall not be judged,' linking judgment of others to one's own judgment.

questions.question: In Luke 6:29, Jesus instructs to offer the other cheek if someone smites you on one. This teaching most closely connects to which Old Testament concept?
options: Turning the other cheek as a radical non-retaliation ethic
An eye for an eye justice (lex talionis)
The law of the talmudic sages
questions.correctAnswer: Turning the other cheek as a radical non-retaliation ethic
questions.explanation: Jesus' teaching in Luke 6:29 contrasts with the Old Testament principle of lex talionis by advocating non-retaliation and mercy.

theological.title: Luke Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Luke Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Luke 6, how does Jesus justify His disciples plucking grain on the Sabbath?
options: He refers to David eating the shewbread which was lawful only for priests
He claims the Sabbath is no longer binding
He says the disciples were not aware it was the Sabbath
He states that plucking grain is not work
questions.correctAnswer: He refers to David eating the shewbread which was lawful only for priests
questions.explanation: Jesus refers to the example of David eating the shewbread when hungry, which was lawful only for priests, to show mercy and human need supersede certain Sabbath restrictions (Luke 6:3-4). This aligns with the principle in 1 Samuel 21:1-6 and Hosea 6:6 emphasizing mercy over sacrifice, and Matthew 12:7 confirming Jesus' teaching.

questions.question: What title does Jesus claim for Himself in relation to the Sabbath in Luke 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Lord of the Sabbath
questions.explanation: Jesus declares Himself 'Lord also of the sabbath' (Luke 6:5), asserting His authority over the Sabbath command, which corresponds with His divine lordship as seen in Mark 2:28 and John 5:17-18. This reveals His divinity and authority over God's law.

questions.question: Why did the Pharisees watch Jesus closely in the synagogue on the Sabbath?
options: To find an accusation because He might heal on the Sabbath
Because they wanted to learn from Him
To invite Him to teach more often
To ask Him about the law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: To find an accusation because He might heal on the Sabbath
questions.explanation: The Pharisees watched Jesus to find a reason to accuse Him, particularly if He healed on the Sabbath (Luke 6:7). This reflects their legalistic interpretation of Sabbath laws, similar to the opposition Jesus faced in Matthew 12:9-14 and John 9:14-16.

questions.question: What question does Jesus ask to challenge the Pharisees about healing on the Sabbath?
options: Is it lawful to do good or to do evil on the Sabbath?
Is the Sabbath made for man or man for the Sabbath?
Do you honor the Sabbath or your traditions?
questions.correctAnswer: Is it lawful to do good or to do evil on the Sabbath?
questions.explanation: Jesus asks whether it is lawful to do good or evil, to save life or destroy it on the Sabbath (Luke 6:9), emphasizing the intent of the law is mercy and preservation of life, consistent with Jeremiah 7:22-23 and Hosea 6:6.

questions.question: What was the result when Jesus healed the man with the withered hand?
options: His hand was restored whole as the other
The man remained withered but was comforted
questions.correctAnswer: His hand was restored whole as the other
questions.explanation: Jesus commanded the man to stretch forth his hand, and it was restored completely (Luke 6:10). This miracle demonstrated Jesus' divine authority and power to heal, as also seen in Matthew 12:13 and Mark 3:5.

questions.question: After healing the man on the Sabbath, what was the reaction of the scribes and Pharisees?
options: They were filled with madness and plotted against Jesus
They asked the healed man to testify
questions.correctAnswer: They were filled with madness and plotted against Jesus
questions.explanation: The Pharisees were enraged and conspired what to do to Jesus (Luke 6:11), showing their opposition to His messianic work, paralleling opposition in John 11:53 and Matthew 26:3-4.

questions.question: How many apostles did Jesus choose after praying all night on the mountain?
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve
questions.explanation: Jesus chose twelve apostles after all-night prayer (Luke 6:13), fulfilling the symbolic number representing the twelve tribes of Israel, foundational for the new covenant community, consistent with Matthew 10:1-4 and Acts 1:13.

questions.question: Which of these was NOT named among the twelve apostles in Luke 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: Paul is not listed among the twelve apostles chosen by Jesus in Luke 6:14-16; he became an apostle later through revelation (Acts 9:1-19). The twelve listed include Peter, James, and Judas Iscariot.

questions.question: What blessing does Jesus pronounce upon the poor in spirit in Luke 6?
options: Theirs is the kingdom of God
questions.correctAnswer: Theirs is the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Jesus declares 'Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God' (Luke 6:20), highlighting God's preferential option for the humble, consistent with Matthew 5:3 and Isaiah 61:1-3.

questions.question: According to Luke 6, what is Jesus' teaching on loving enemies?
options: Love your enemies and do good to those who hate you
Love only those who love you
Avoid your enemies to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: Love your enemies and do good to those who hate you
questions.explanation: Jesus commands love for enemies and doing good to those who hate you (Luke 6:27), underscoring the radical ethic of the Kingdom, echoed in Matthew 5:44 and Romans 12:20-21.

questions.question: What principle does Jesus teach in Luke 6 about how we should treat others?
options: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
questions.correctAnswer: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches the Golden Rule: 'as ye would that men should do to you, do ye also to them likewise' (Luke 6:31). This principle is foundational in ethical teaching, also seen in Matthew 7:12 and Leviticus 19:18.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give about judging others in Luke 6?
options: Judge not, and ye shall not be judged
Judge everyone strictly to maintain order
questions.correctAnswer: Judge not, and ye shall not be judged
questions.explanation: Jesus warns against judgmentalism, promising reciprocal mercy if we forgive and do not condemn (Luke 6:37). This aligns with Matthew 7:1-5 and Romans 14:10-13 emphasizing humility and mercy.

questions.question: In the parable Jesus spoke in Luke 6, what happens when the blind lead the blind?
options: They both fall into the ditch
questions.correctAnswer: They both fall into the ditch
questions.explanation: Jesus says the blind leading the blind will both fall into the ditch (Luke 6:39), illustrating the danger of following false teachers, consistent with Proverbs 19:27 and Matthew 15:14.

questions.question: According to Luke 6, what is the analogy Jesus uses for a person who hears His words and acts on them?
options: Like a man who builds a house on a rock
Like a seed sown on rocky ground
Like a bird building a nest in a tree
questions.correctAnswer: Like a man who builds a house on a rock
questions.explanation: Jesus compares the obedient person to one who builds a house on rock, able to withstand floods (Luke 6:48). This is a metaphor for spiritual stability, also found in Matthew 7:24-27 and Psalm 18:2.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the person who hears His words but does not do them?
options: Like a man who built a house without foundation that falls in a flood
questions.correctAnswer: Like a man who built a house without foundation that falls in a flood
questions.explanation: Jesus states that those who hear but do not act are like a house built without foundation that collapses (Luke 6:49), symbolizing spiritual ruin, as also warned in James 1:22-25 and Proverbs 10:25.
